etymologies: Old English. Apparently from Old English rifian to become wrinkled + -le

definitions: To become wrinkled or shrivelled; to form wrinkles or small folds.

notes.text: In early use especially of the skin, now chiefly of paint, varnish, or some similar coating.

definitions: To cause (something, especially the skin) to wrinkle, pucker, or shrivel. Also with up. Also without object. Now rare (in later use poetic and English regional (west midlands)).

etymologies: late Middle English (in an earlier sense). Origin uncertain. Perhaps from Middle French rivler to ravel (although this is first attested later: 1530 in Palsgrave; French regional (Walloon) si rifler to fray), probably a specifically use of rifler

definitions: To unravel, untangle (literal and figurative). Chiefly with † up, out.
